description:
Great tamales Guatemaltecos!

The tamales Guatemaltecos are very similar to the ones in in Oaxaca and Veracruz in Mexico. I miss my Veracruz tamales (Cooked in banana leaves). These ones, just add spicy salsa (Ask for it), and it's just as good!
author: Federico A.

description:
Kind of a weird ordering set-up here. 

To your left when you walk in a ordering station. They have meats listed on the menu board but there are others available so you have to ask. 

I didn't know this so I had to ask the lady "Do you have al pastor"? 

The time to cook the tacos actually took a little bit longer than some of the other venues as well. 

The taco itself was decent but not spectacular by any means either. 

The world needs a San Francisco Taco ranking...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top) is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places.  

Rod's SF Taco Rankings:

2 Garajito
3 Belmar La Gallinita Meat Market
4 La Corneta
5 Chisme
6 El Norteno Taco Truck

10 Taqueria Los Mayas
author: Rod M.

description:
I have never had a bad meal from this place.
I tried the Atol de Avena (drink), so nice and smooth.
the person that work there (Ricardo) was always so nice in answering all my questions and also gave me samples of the thing I asked.
today I also tried their Guatemalan style Tamal.
you can either order it Mexican style or Guatemalan style.
Guatemalan style are softer than the Mexican style.
this is the place for Tamales, Super Burrito Carne Asada, Chicharrones, and Caldo de Res.
my favorite Taqueria!
author: Rudy H.

description:
Very authentic but sort of disappointing after seeing all these rave reviews. The typical kind of spot I love for mexican food a dive with 100% hispanic people dining there, and the menu only in spanish to the point where as a Peruvian myself I couldnt tell what a few of the items were. I ordered a pork tamale amd cheese pupusa and both were nice and cheap.

 The tamale was already ready which makes sense given the process and the flavors were on point but it was almost all corn with a lunch meat slice size ammount of shredded pork inside rather then being stuffed. I had to wait 45 minutes or so for the to go cheese pupusa which is essentially a corn based cheese quesadilla you just toss on the huge grill for a couple minutes when it wasnt very busy but service was friendly and chill. It tasted good and had tons of cheese(who dosnt like plate full of melted cheese?) My only qualm and I say this as a non health nut who loves my greasy foods was it had a few inches deep of pure liquid cheese grease on the plate. I was too hungry to care and about went into a food coma on the walk home but it could have easily been dabbed with some paper towels before serving.
author: Sean G.

description: Incredibly cheap, authentic food! The Guatemalan tamale was so fresh and to die for. Pupusas and tacos were delicious too, though perhaps not as unique as the aforementioned tamale. The environment was cozy and communal, but don't expect anything fancy. The portion sizes were good and I was totally filled from this meal despite being a big eater. I have a sensitive stomach when eating out but had no problems here and would definitely go again!
author: J L.

description: Staff is friendly and the food is cheap and good. I like the tacos and tamales. The pupusas and burritos aren't bad. They have fast, convenient breakfast options like tamales and atol de elote. I do wish they had complementary chips and salsa or a salsa bar. All in all it's a decent and reliable place to fill your stomach.
author: Alan X.

description:
Pretty delicious burritos, although it seems like they are known more for their pupusas and tamales.  We had serious food envy after ordering and realizing that everyone else had ordered a pupusa/tamale.  But, that's okay because the burrito was very satisfying and hit just the right spot.  Good amount of spice, delicious guacamole, and yummy crunchy and chewy bits of chicharonnes hidden inside.  I'm pretty sure my carne asada burrito was not supposed to come with chicharonnes, but it did.  And, I'm not complaining.

I will echo though some of the comments of other Yelpers that they are rather slow.  It honestly appeared as if there was only one chef in the back and the orders were coming out one-by-one.  By taqueria standards, this was a rather slow process and what we thought would only be a 10-15 minute stop turned into 20-25 minutes which was much more than we had allotted for.
author: Jess Y.

description: Very good place to buy the best fry pork skin and carnitas. Super. Delicious. Everytime I go that area. I have to buy some pounds of carnitas
author: Carmen L.

description: Still the best ! Every year we visit SF, and every year we set aside a day to come here for pupusas, sweet corn tamales, and atol de elote. Popular with locals and tourists alike, the place only has seven tables, so get here either early or later, or take your food to go. We have never had a bad meal from this place.
author: Veronica S.

description:
I ventured here for my first mission burrito. I'm usually a fan of tier two rated things - i.e., where Taqueria Vallarta unanimously tops lists, La Espiga seems to pop up below, and for me that means a place that may not have succumbed to its popularity too quickly. I will report back from Vallarta another time!

This burrito was incredible. I got the super asada. Really awesome deal for $9. The cheese was a nice factor - it melted in such a way as to really round out the consistency. 

One downside is that they don't seem to equipped to speak in English. I spoke in Spanish, but that might give some new customers anxiety if there's a little barrier. Also means more authenticity.
author: Chris K.

description: I absolutely love this place, the food is amazing and I feel like they have a good variety of items to order. I usually always get the order of flautas and the pupusas. The order of flautas come with just two but they are so good. And the pupusas are amazing I recommend the chicharron and queso. The only bad part is the location because it is so difficult to find parking and if you do find parking it's usually metered parking. But whenever I am in the area and craving Mexican food this is one of the places that's at the top of my list.
author: Vanessa D.

description: This place has a good burrito. I love that they are open at 7am because I can go there while on my way to work. The burrito is a nice size and has a ratio of meat to other ingredients. It's always got customers which is a plus even that early in the morning. And they have a lot of stuff on the menu. So far I've only had the burritos several times. I will definitely me back to try more menu items.
author: Arielle W.

description:
The lady taking our order spoke zero English so it was tough to get what I wanted

The bean and cheese papusa was good, not great.  I had to ask for the curtido (cabbage slaw) and was given an itty bitty portion, maybe a tablespoon.   

The beef soup was extremely bland.

I wouldn't bother ever coming back here. Although the people working were super sweet
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Overpriced dry tacos. 

Not my usual spot, but I was doing laundry across the street, so I figured I'd try something new. Ordered 3 carne asada super tacos. The meat was dry, avocado was hard and overall the tacos were tasteless. I tried to squeeze more lime on them to trick my mouth into thinking they were edible, but gave up. Also, salsa portions are absurdly small. 

Giving 2 stars instead of 1 because based on their other reviews, I must've caught them on an off day. Unfortunately it was such a bad experience that I won't be back to give it another shot.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I felt I was in Mexico after being at this place. I loved the atole de nuez and the green chiken tamales.
My fiance had the had the carnitas burrito and it was amazing!! 
This place is a must if you're looking for authentic south Mexico taste!
author: Ivy C.

description:
FOOD: I came here for pupusas and was not disappointed! Only had the frijol y queso to go, but I loved them both and the curtido (cabbage salad) was tangy and flavorful. I will have to come back for the tamales :). 

SERVICE: Friendly and relatively fast. I appreciate that the line is never as long here to order (don't know why) to grab some excellent, inexpensive takeout. It can take a little while for the food to arrive, but appreciate that this is because it's being made fresh. 

AMBIANCE: Hole in the wall, open air restaurant--you order at a window where you are separated from the cashier... a bit like a drive-through! Limited counter seating inside where you can eat or wait for your food.
author: Helen W.

description:
The best burrito on the planet, hands down. SF's ultimate arbiter of burritotaste that was Burritoeater.com may now be defunct but his assertion that this hole-in-the-wall has no rival continues to be true to this day.

WHY is this the best burrito? It's a combination of key elements. First, all of their ingredients are fresh and well-prepared; you're getting actual marinated carne asada in these burritos and not just charred brisket that is only redeemed as part of other more favorable components. The combination of cheese, rice, and beans is really unusual and savory in a way that's difficult to describe other than I've never had anything quite like it in another burrito. And, they grill the tortilla perfectly so you have the right amount of crunchy texture and smoke complimenting the contents of the burrito and not some wet, spongy, elastic mess like you often get at La Taqueria. Carne Asada and Super Pollo burritos here are seriously the best.

Other menu items are quite good as well. Cheese pupusas are extremely flavorful and rich. The Guisado De Chile Verde dish is extremely hearty and full of very generous chunks of pork - warning, this one is over-the-top as far as heartiness is concerned so if you're like me you might get a little overwhelmed by the richness of the pork in this dish.

The only con really is that the location is pretty inconvenient to all public transport so you'll likely need to either drive here or pay $20+ for you burrito via Postmates. Even then I'd say it's worth it.
author: Matt M.

description: This place is more of a fast stop. You would first order at the counter before finding a seat. They bring you your food and no one really bothers you. I ordered the Pork Tamales. This was decent, but I know I have had better. Maybe next time I'll order something else. Authentic I wouldn't know, but I would agree that this is place is a must try if you're ever on 24th street in the Mission area.
author: Hailey V.

description: I was introduced to this restaurant by my husband  They have all kinds of food like, burritos, pupusas and tortas, etc.  But their tamales are just to-die-for. The tamales Guatemala style are so good -- not like the typical Mexican tamales which is mostly masa, these are really soft and I would say almost like Filipino tamales. Anytime I am craving tamales, I will always go to this place now.  I don't know of any other place that serve tamales as good as this place.  IF YOU WANT THE BEST TAMALES, GO TO THIS PLACE.
author: Bernadette A.

description:
This place is always wall-to-wall, it is. That's why it's taken me so long to give it a try, but I was strolling on 24th in the middle of a brisk Saturday afternoon. Truth be told, I had already had lunch in the Castro and wasn't really hungry. Still, it was the rare sight of this place in a nearly empty state that forced my mind to go into a clickety-clack mode trying to justify having a snack here before dinner. I had heard so much about La Espiga De Oro from various foodie blogs that I thought a little indigestion would be a worthy price to pay to get a taste of the food here. As I walked up slowly to the small order window, I began to notice how comprehensive the overhead menu was. I needed to study it and let others go ahead of me.

Ah, I see pupusas. Just one would do me, so I ordered the $2.99 Pupusa de Queso (photo: http://bit.ly/1FtCqfV). I could tell the masa was freshly made because it had a silkier texture than most, but it was rightfully blistered from being hot off the grill. The cheese was already oozing out of it from the steam. Some fresh curtido and tomato salsa made the ideal topping (photo: http://bit.ly/1BDi89h). Good stuff. As you guessed, it's a compact spot. There's a dining counter against the wall and a few tables set further back (photo: http://bit.ly/1fowRKP). I'm guessing my future orders will be to go. In case you want to know, La Espiga de Oro means The Golden Spike, which may have some historical reference, but makes me recall one of my favorite watering holes in North Beach. But that's another story...

FOOD - 4 stars...a cheesy pupusa is all I had but it was enough to make me want to come back for more
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...tight fit in here, expect to take it to go
SERVICE - 4 stars...fast if not friendly
TOTAL - 4 stars...usually crazy-busy but this glorified taco stand in the Mission could be worth the trouble for you
author: Ed U.

description:
Ok, I went in and ordered a pupusa and the torta cubana with horchata. First the wait. It took forever, and I even got a ticket waiting. Yeah the meter expired and damn I was pissed as I ran out to feed the meter and the jackass predator still gave me a ticket so as I walk back to get my food I'm all heated up. 

When my food finally came and I took it to go, mistake, the bag was heavy. I get to the car and everything was piping hot. Wrapped in aluminum and almost sizzling. 

The horchata was excellent. Not to thin. Plenty of silky goodness with bold flavor. 

The torta could feed 10 people. It was juicy and just filled with goodness. The pupusa was just too much as I barely made it through my sandwich. Definitely going back soon!
author: Ish A.

description: I was pretty disappointed overall. Looked like a great place and they were making tamales and tortillas in the back. These are generally very good signs. Unfortunately my carne asada burrito was filled with mostly tough, gristly beef. The other fillings were good but it's hard to get past that.
author: Alex H.

description:
First Papusa ever! Got the Papusa y chicharron con queso 

But it's the salsa I have to rave about. I actually dream about this salsa. I have never had salsa that good and I have lived in SOCAL and been on the border...how? I don't know....

They sell it by the tub so make sure to buy that and stock up.
author: Tiffanie T.

description: Okay, I'm perplexed.  I have been purchasing food from this restaurant for a least a year, if not longer.  I eat there, or I order to go, and I really enjoy their food.  My favorite thing to do is to grab a bag or two of their tortilla chips on the way out; they are the best chips in town.  They are actually corn tortillas, fried on premises, I believe.  However, for the past two months, the chips are either stale or just not cooked nicely enough.  I am so disappointed, I don't know what has happened, or where else to go.  Bummer.
author: janice s.

description: I was cruising through the Mish in search of some good eats, went a little further out than the scene on Valencia and 16th area and was pleasantly surprised by this place. I ordered a burrito and pupusa and was stuffed after! Service was great and the food was amazing, and very authentic, super tasty. This place wheels and deals in mainly pupusas, and they seem to crush the tomale scene as well (based on the to-go orders that were picked up by non-gringos), which I mistakenly did not order. But I will be back to get those and another amazing burrito. Super good place, very chill atmosphere as well.
author: Ezra B.

description: The Guatemalan Tamale is better than thanksgiving diners. "So good" is a gross understatement
author: Derrick V.

description:
4.5 stars. Very solid but not epic IMO, shines in some areas and falls short in others.

I had the grilled chicken super burrito.  Great flavor, mixture, temperature, presentation, and fresh ingredients.  They toast their burritos like Cancun so that earns it bonus points.  Fresher avocado would have made it epic.

My wife had a veggie burrito and it was quite good as well.  Same area for improvement as my burrito.

Salsa selection is limited to a super spicy roja salsa and a milder verde salsa.

Service was friendly but a bit slow.  It's definitely a bit run down in terms of decor but nothing more than your average taqueria.  You're not really paying for ambience anyway.

Highly recommended to try, I doubt anyone could be displeased here.
author: Saminda W.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots to eat as it's literally a few steps away from my house. I've tried just about everything on their menu.

My go to are the chicken tacos. I'm usually not a fan of grilled chicken, I prefer boiled, but this place gets it right. The tacos come with nopales (cactus) and salsa (spicy or mild). My favorite thing about the tacos though is that you can choose to have them on handmade tortillas. 

I also really enjoy their arroz con leche. But be warned, their version of arroz con leche is a drink as opposed to a pudding. Still very good, not too sweet. 

The only item that I've tried and am not too crazy about are their pupusas. They're a bit too greasy for my liking.
author: Marycruz M.

description:
I'm so disappointed in myself for not knowing about this place sooner, and always going to El Farolito instead. I honestly think their burritos here are way more delicious - the carne asada is super juicy and flavorful. They wrap their burritos excellently - everything is even out and the flavors mixes so well together. When I don't ask for any beans, I feel like it's a burrito filled with 3:1 ratio of meat to rice.. which is so awesome! 

I highly recommended this place if you ever come to the Mission area!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Wednesday night- walking home from work and feel like a burrito. Stopped in and ordered a simple bean and cheese burrito to-go. It wasn't too busy, many 7 other customers in the joint. The girl working the cashier was friendly. I then proceeded to wait for my burrito:

10 mins. 20 mins. 30 mins goes by. 

I worked in the restaurant biz for several years in college so am generally very patient and polite but this seemed odd. I went up to ask the girl who I ordered from and she proceeded to tell me the cook couldn't make my burrito and she needed to give me my money back. REALLY?! You let me sit there for 35 mins waiting for one effing burrito only to tell me you can't make it?!? I will never be going back here- worst experience ever.
author: Emma V.

description:
Girl at counter is super nice, but knows about 2 works of English! It was fun trying to figure out how to order with her. 

No wait to order, but our food took a while. We had to ask them for extra bowls/spoons, but they were super nice about it - a bit understaffed with what seems like 1 chef, 1 girl at the register, and 1 other girl as an in-between. 

Cost: About $33 for 1 soup, 1 pupusa, 2 tacos, 1 quesadilla, and a small horchata.

Must-haves: Pupusas! Chorizo taco!!

* Sopa Caldo de Res (pork rib soup w/ veggies. $9.99) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-espiga-de-oro-san-francisco?select=ABjnUevUDUX91YvgZDYJ2Q#ABjnUevUDUX91YvgZDYJ2Q
A simple & good comfort food - huge chunks of fatty soft pork rib, potato, some sort of radish, carrots. All came in a giant bowl that easily split into three. My mom really loved this - reminiscent of our homemade pork broths. The corn tortillas were thick and had a homemade feel, but were a bit dry. The little container of rice was actually quite flavorful & moist too! Also came with red pickled onions and cilantro. I wasn't really sure how to eat everything together but 

* Pupusa De Revueltas (beans, pork, & cheese. $2.99) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-espiga-de-oro-san-francisco?select=ABjnUevUDUX91YvgZDYJ2Q#ailIGq8os2iQXq7p_2rh-g
Yum! Still the best I've had in SF. Thick, crispy outer layer. Inside gooey and warm, w/ plenty of filling, good ratio of beans to pork to cheese. Came with salsa and 

* Taco Chorizo, Super ($3.49) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-espiga-de-oro-san-francisco?select=ABjnUevUDUX91YvgZDYJ2Q#-qjlKvN1O2MjKF8cAjfycg
As before, love the crispness of their chorizo, and their sharp seasonings - great flavor! I have to qualify this by saying that my bf found the meat dry though. And we got the super, but I really am not sure what makes it super as it was mostly chorizo and cilantro.

* Taco Carnitas, Super ($3.49) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-espiga-de-oro-san-francisco?select=ABjnUevUDUX91YvgZDYJ2Q#SB5qCmNQK30R6CDJGT8gbw
I found these carnitas to be quite dry and tough, but my mom and bf both really liked it. Maybe I tend to like very tender & moist carnitas but this is just a different style. I think super means that they added pickled green beans on top - I really didn't like this at all.

* Quesadilla, Tortillo de Harina, Carne Asada ($8.99) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-espiga-de-oro-san-francisco?select=ABjnUevUDUX91YvgZDYJ2Q#Fj5WPDb8v9eA2FU4dQCCqQ
I like that this wasn't your typical pressed-flat-covered-in-melted-cheese quesadilla. It was a fresh flour tortilla wrapped around the meat & cheese - and there was a good balance of both. It was the fattest quesadilla I've ever had - a good, large quantity of food. I thought the beef was soft and flavorful (I do have to say my bf thought the meat wasn't fresh, was too heavy/greasy, and that this was his least favorite dish). On the side were avocado slices, sour cream, & diced onion/tomato/cilantro.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Wow - this place has amazing food!  The only reason I'm giving 4 stars instead of 5 is that the food took a long time to come out.

My husband and I shared four items, all of which were delicious!  We had:

1) Guatemalan chicken tamale (a tamale steamed in Banana leaf) - flavorful and reasonably healthy
2) Chicken taco - great
3) Carne Asada taco - excellent
4) Pupusa with chicharrones (tasty, and we appreciated that they made this without cheese for us)

Ordering was a bit tricky, as the staff had limited English ability.  

The food was very affordable, and our entire meal was less than $14. 

Our only frustration was that the tacos and pupusa took forever to come out.  Fortunately, the tamale was pre made and served right away, so we were able to satiate our hungry stomachs while we waited.

The space was no frills, but pleasant.

Overall, a great find!
author: Barnali D.

description: Got the carne asada burrito.  Delicious.  My wife got a taco and it was plenty for her.  Will definitely be back.
author: Tom L.

description:
Everything is fantastic but you may get harassed by homeless people who they feed frequently when you are inside, unfortunately.  

The people who work here are really nice but I wish the people receiving free food could be more respectful of the business and not aggressively ask for money to buy booze.  I was made fun of and laughed at for a few minutes the last time I was in the place by two drunks when I refused to give them money for beer.

They stay away when the owner is there, which is quite often, but when he is not there it's almost a free-for-all.
author: Jeremy B.

description: I regularly crave the Guatemalan tamales and papusas from this place. It is a cafeteria style restaurant so you order at the front and then sit down to eat. It feels really local and is a real gem in the city.
author: Mitch C.

description: I honestly do not know what restaurant you all visited. Terrible pupusas, stale tortillas, ancient slaw, incredibly slow service.
author: Hawley S.

description:
Came here on a Monday around 12:30PM. Parking wasn't too bad to find on 24th St, since many people hate paying for parking. The place was a bit empty when we first walked in.

Ordered a carne asada super burrito and my friend ordered some tacos. The wait for the food was a little longer than I expected since there was not many people there... I think we waited 10-15 minutes for our food. Finally got our food and the burrito was solid, it wasn't bad nor did it have a wow factor. The carnitas in my friend's tacos were dry and they got one of her tacos wrong (she ordered a super taco and instead she got the regular - only a $1 difference so it wasn't a huge deal). Plus, the pickled peppers on the tacos were slimy which was off putting. Our food came with 1 small bag of chips and 1 salsa cup. There was no salsa bar but two bottles of hot sauce out, a salsa verde and salsa rojo.

The cashier who helped us was nice, I would come here again only for the burritos.
author: Lorina L.

description:
Before coming here, I didn't know what pupusas were. Now I know that pupusas are life.

I'm almost hesitant to write a review about this place because I'd like it to stay a hole-in-the-wall. Down on 24th St and far removed from Mission St, this spot doesn't get as much foot traffic as taqueria juggernauts such as El Farolito and La Taqueria. But if there's one thing I know it's burritos (and probably nothing else), and this is the new best. Taqueria Cancun has been officially usurped as my all time favorite

Pupusas?? Get them. Not too greasy, excellent salsa, beans & cheese & pork make for one mean pupusa. The food does take a little while to come out (by taqueria standards) and the interior is a little janky, but nevertheless Espiga de Oro has captured by heart. Try it out. Actually don't, stay away.
author: Bud P.

description: Delicious pupusas! Passed it every day for 3 months on my way to work at the hospital, and finally decided to check it out. Inexpensive, but absolutely delicious. Loved seeing all the different types of dishes that were coming out of the kitchen. Many families ordered caldo. It was quite a wait for my order with a couple other orders in front of me, but the cashier was friendly, and the food was fantastic -- my roommates concurred.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
Guatemalan food. It's a taqueria, with all the usual Mexican dishes, but also has Guatemalan food, my first time.

The tamale de Guatemala is excellent, soft boiled corn inside a banana leaf with delish chicken, light spices, and tomato. Definitely try it $4.50.

The corn tortilla taco is always really good and filling ($3). Comes w unique veggies and the asada is high quality as well. 

El Farolito is a block away, but that line is always long (deservingly so), so definitely try this spot out.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Returned with a friend who was visiting from NYC where we all know there's no good burrito. This time I got the super carnitas burrito as recommended by BurritoEater but couldn't resist getting the chicharron papusa. 

Big mistake.

Those papusas are pretty big. Enough for a light lunch. I thought I wouldn't be able to eat my burrito at all but I toughened up and pushed on to finish at least half. 

Pretty good burrito. Pretty wet and tasty. Unfortunately wet doesn't translate to good leftovers. By the next day it was kinda a soggy mess. Still yummy as long as I didn't think about the cold mushy tortilla wrapped around the filling. It was worth it though since most burritos are kinda dry. No need for hot sauce for flavor or to help digestive juices with this one!
author: Jean K.

description:
In my opinion, Espiga is the most underrated burrito in SF.  I wouldn't be sad if it stayed that way either. 

I had the super carne asada.  Size was perfect.  Tortilla was quality and heated to a slight crisp.  Meat was excellent.  Cheese was as good as you could ask, and was spread throughout evenly.
author: Tom F.

description:
Authentic. If you are looking for a healing chicken soup, look no further! 

I'll definitely be back to try everything.
author: Bulldog W.

description:
I always knew of chicharones as those fried, crunchy "chips" sold in convenience stores. I steered clear as it was a) not very appetizing-looking, b) unclear what it was comprised of, and c) insanely carb- and fat-ridden.

La Espiga quelled my fear and introduced me to the wonderful world of chicharones. They looked like odd-shaped churros sitting under a red lamp, so I asked the lady behind the counter what it was. She handed me a piece and I fell in love at first bite: crunchy, chewy, salty pork goodness. That's what it was. (Although we didn't, you may purchase these by the pound.) And since we were there for a solid meal, we also went with:

+Super nachos with carnitas (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-espiga-de-oro-san-francisco?select=93ONlferBBmrHopvsQMZaQ#103LlR4duL_lzcqq-wqXHw). No guacamole, it's straight avocado slices for you, with jalapenos, pico de gallo, melted cheese, and refried beans. Delicious.

+Asada burrito (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-espiga-de-oro-san-francisco?select=iZPh71VHvUsomcNAqd31bA#iZPh71VHvUsomcNAqd31bA). The reason I came here (thanks, Casey U., for that awesome review)! Incredibly juicy, non-gristly beef, beans, cheese, and pico de gallo. My new favorite carne burrito.

The space left a little something to be desired, but I didn't care. The footie match was on, mariachi music blared in the background, and I had burrito grease running down the side of my chin: all was good in this world.
author: Adena B.

description:
i've been here once, and i'm sold. fresh tamales at dirt cheap prices! perfectly succulent carnitas! deliciously spicy flavorful house salsa! right next door to a wonderful inexpensive mexican market and carniceria giving me ample excuse to frequent this taco joint on a weekly basis! even the beans in my taco failed to offend me, as they are want to do to any angelina worth her yucateco. (side note: WHAT IS HAPPENING TO ME?)  cannot wait to go back!

also, rookie tip: they do not speak english here. brush up on that high school spanish to order or reply on google translate/ hand gestures to make it through. it is well worth the effort!
author: Archana P.

description:
My first visit here was 2 days ago. I had a carne asada taco and a horchata. The food took a little while to come out, because they cook the meat to order. Hot, succulent, sabroso. So delicious, and deeply emotionally satisfying. The horchata was also perfect. Everyone else in the place was Latino, and eating a bowl of soup. 

Today I'm back with my boyfriend. We repeated the carne asada tacos, and also got a caldo de res (beef soup). I was moved again. I'm thinking this is the best soup I've ever had, or just damn good anyway. Really, a thing of beauty. 

My bf had to order a second taco, thwarting his burning man diet. :). He said it was the best corn tortilla he had ever tasted. 

The service was warm and accommodating both visits. It's just a little place with a few tables. When I walked back through the kitchen to the bathroom, I saw the corn soaking in huge vats to make the masa that they use for tamales, and sell to the public. I'm smitten.
author: jessica h.

description: 5 stars for this tiny hole in the wall because it has 12 varieties of tamales from Guatemalan to Mexican and even vegetetarian.  The tamales are handmade, the tortillas as well - they grind their own cornmeal in back.  It's not the most beautiful or even clean place but the place is as authentic as you can get.   I ordered a Guatemalan chuchito and Mexican carnitas tamale which were delicious'
author: Jean Y.

description: Ok so I've had many pupusas before.  Several homemade.  The pupusas here were awesome.  I will have to come back to try more things but if you only come once be sure to get the pupusas.  Yummy!!!
author: Thadeus K.

description:
My absolute favorite burrito spot when looking for the "traditional" Super Burrito. 

There's a couple of places I'd go instead if I was looking for super chimichangas or fried stuffed burritos but for the traditional super this place does things perfectly. They have a pretty solid selection of meats and everything tastes like they make all the practical parts of the burrito to order.

The tacos are also fantastic and pretty huge for price (basically salad's worth of topping on each shell) and do a good job of highlighting all their amazing meats offered.

They also get like a million bonus points for opening at 6 am and serve what I think is the best breakfast burrito in the Mission (AT 6 FUCKING AM!! LOOKING AT YOU 11AM FAROLITO!!!)

Chicharrones are also on point, crunchy, chewy, fatty, and amazing.

One thing I gotta note is their pupusas are kinda of dry and leathery compared to the authentic Salvadorean restaurants, not a bad thing but notably different, personally I'd go to La Palma and get their pupusas instead or most of the other places that offer them. In my experience the places with lame burritos have better pupusas *shrug*

TLDR: Get the super burritos, tacos, opt out of the pupusas, put chicharrones and steak on everything.
author: Jeff T.

description:
I probably wouldn't have come here if one of my friends did not recommend this place.  It's a hole in the wall that didn't have any customers at the time. I'm so glad I tried this place. This was a first for El Salvadorean food and shall not be the last. 

The pupusa revuelta was amazing! It's like a calzone with a tortilla covering, stuffed with pork, beans, and cheese. The cheese was melted in with the other ingredients, served warm out of the oven.  Omg. So good. I couldn't stop eating it until it was gone. 

Tamal Chiapenco chicken Mole was similar to the traditional Mexican tamale, but with a very different outside. This one had a very soft and moist shell and not made of masa. It was good.

I would definitely come back for the pupusa.
author: Theresa D.

description:
Came to this Mexicatessen http://media2.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-LRljemkbjFlqQHgIl1Lzw/l to buy meat by the pound ($7.50/lb.): carnitas and chicharron (not pork rinds) for a holiday potluck party last year. Service was excellent, she took the time to bag and tie each bag with tape to avoid leaks. http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5r4sMyUlmidYwSwk7zPQsA/l My favorite are the carnitas, delicious!! See my pic after reheating and chopping. http://media2.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Zr4vqMXtK5RtGAgbHdRtHg/l

The tamales are okay. http://media3.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kMi5LtJsMJJ3mVitSZHocg/l Tamales Unicos de Cuernavaca in Oakland is much better for Mexican tamales. My favorite remains Peruvian tamales.

Hours: daily 6am-7pm
author: Luis C.

description: Wow this place is such a gem. You can't tell from standing outside of the store that this place has amazing TAMALES. All of their tamales are made fresh here and there are so many different options! From savory meats to sweet dessert tamales! The hot sauces that they offer are perfect and super spicy for the savory tamales. The owners are super sweet here and they have amazing tamales!!! I'll have to try the rest of the menu next time, but so far, this place hits home for A M A Z I N G  TAMALES!
author: Jane N.

description: Yummy, delicioso, sabroso. I had the gorditas de chicharron. Heavenly delicious, friendly staff!
author: Riley C.

description: So authentic, the register didn't speak English -- nice opp to practice my Spanish. Very friendly, burrito was great. Still haven't found a place in SF that beats the Mexican food in San Jose though.
author: Hamed E.

description:
Rivaling the Miami Heat for the greatest consolidation of power since the Roman Empire, La Espiga's thorough collection of supremely flavorful Mexican cuisine eliminates the common, 24th Street-centric quandary of deciding a dining destination while juggling the limits of single-specialty shops and split preferences.

The Carne Asada burrito is arguably the best in the neighborhood, featuring a grilled and delightfully charred tortilla, tons of tender meat, and an ample amount of cheese to permeate and unite the fillings. The well-know synergistic effects of Carne Asada juices and soft, orange beads of oil that is absent in many neighboring taquerias is fully showcased in each bite of this magnificently complete burrito.

The Carnitas burrito, that is stuffed so full of soft, seasoned meat, is obviously the byproduct of a chef with Thanksgiving-leftover Syndrome, which is characterized by the calculated urge to fill the Black Friday lunch sandwich with as much turkey as possible just to get it out of sight.  The Pollo burrito contains seasoned breast meat that is significantly less tender than the Carne Asada or Carnitas, but undoubtedly healthier and still tasty.

When desiring lunch on a budget or a feast accessory, the homemade Tamales offer a rich, maize flavor and satisfactory proportion of meat, and can be dutifully assisted by the tangy, green salsa that impresses more with taste than spice in the squeeze bottles on the counter. 

The pieces of Chicharron are kept warm at regulation temperatures, preserving its crispy exterior and fatty, acne-inducing interior in perfect balance, and the Papusas offer a substantially dense snack that dependably oozes melted cheese.

Do not look any further, because La Espiga will fulfill any Mexican-food craving in this part of town!
author: Andrew M.

description:
I stumbled into here because sugarlump hadnt opened yet and it was very rewarding. 

First, I knew it was legit because i was the whitest (culturally speaking) person there and im indian. Second, their breakfast burrito did not have any rice or beans or any fillers. It was just eggs, chorizo and cheese so I didn't feel too guilty. Third, I learned in india that if the local population did not eat at a restaurant that i shouldn't, and Espiga had plenty of locals so it was locally verified in my book. 

K go eat here now.
author: Danny D.

description:
I have tasted tamales all over 24th and this place has the best pork and chicken tamales I've ever had. They are delicious and you can actually taste the meat ( I know how bad this sounds!). 

My second favorite thing on the menu is the atol the nuez, is like hot chocolate but made out of walnut (hope I got the right translation), it is simply amazing. If I lived closer, I would have this daily instead of coffee.

I like that it is very affordable, and portions are decent. I have only tried their tamales and pupusas as it goes for food. The pupusas are also the best ones I've ever had. I recommend the chicharron and cheese pupusas, so so so tasty and the melted cheese, yummy!

The ladies here are always smiling as well, so makes your whole visit even better. This is not a sit down restaurant, they do have a couple of tables but is more of a pick up and go type of place.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: This place right here , bruh. Guatemala tamales, sopa de res/pollo to die for. The people hella nice and the food never fails. It's cheap too. I can always count on Espiga to feed me when times are rough.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Super Carne Asada burrito was impressive from first bite to finish. Very generous amounts of meat. Nice big fresh slices of avocado. Their Carne asada is really flavorful. 

Their salsa roja was awesome...great flavor. I like cilantro so i loved it. 

It would've been 5 stars but I felt it was kinda greasy.  Also, a friend got the super pollo burrito and it was a lot bigger. So there's some inconsistency in size. (We're talking about burritos people!...keep it clean)
author: Craig I.

description:
All I remember is grease.  The pupusas are smothered in oil.  The burritos are tasty and filling with a lot of rice.  I'm not sure why this place has such good ratings, but perhaps it's because they sweeten the deal with free samples of their delicious rice puddings.

Service is fast and friendly.  However, the staff isn't good at describing what they offer.  Parking is tough on the street.
author: Jenny L.

description: Best pupusas I have had. Very friendly staff. Right next to Humphrey slocombes ice cream. Good combo to end the day. What tempt me most are the chicharon strips on the counter. But that will be for another day.
author: John Z.

description: No credit card and no suggestions on where to find an ATM. Was about to order food for four people so they lost out. Smelled decent and looked clean enough though.
author: Ron P.

description:
Despite having utterly bizarre hours (opening earlier than many coffee shops, closing literally right at the peak of dinner), La Espiga De Oro is probably the best overall taqueria I've been to in my two years here. And that's coming from someone who probably eats his weight in burritos every couple months.

Usually I get a carne asada or chorizo burrito, and it's almost always simply on point. These folks must be wizards when it comes to perfectly grilling a tortilla in particular-- it's almost as flaky and delicious as a damn pie crust. The size is usually ample, the meat is tasty, and even the chips are quality (something a surprising number of places fail miserably at). 

As if their unassailable burritos  weren't enough, this place may also be the king of "dizzying number of good items". The pupusas and tamales are also some of the best anywhere; the Guatemalan tamale in particular is awesome (and huge). Not enough? You can also buy huge slabs of chicarrones if you're in a particularly heart-punishing mood. The champurrado is great, although what I really love is their atol de elote (a hot corn-based drink, which I only ever tried because they gave me a free cup as they were finishing off the batch). 

To round out the ridiculousness, they make their own tortillas, and you can buy masa as well (I use it in my chili). 

Oh, and the people who work here are some of the nicest you'll ever find. Plus the inside kind of looks like a pre-K classroom with its bright yellow walls. And yet somehow on a street with its fair share of hipster yelp juggernauts, nobody knows what I'm talking about when I mention La Espiga de Oro. Maybe they just need to start serving $3 donuts.
author: Bill H.

description:
There's Latin American food next door and across the street. I have to pass five places with tamales, tacos and/or burritos just to get here. We're in the heart of the Mission, so they're everywhere. So how do you find the best?

Answer:

1. Yelp it up
2. Eat before 2 AM
3. Follow the locals.

You want a place where the memories make you salivate? You want a no hassle, friendly dining experience? You want one of the best places the Mission has to offer?

You found it.

At La Espiga de Oro the locals are as authentic as the food, and the vibe is as friendly as it would be if you were south of the border. 

The standard tacos and burritos work like they should, but I stick with a tried and true combo: a pupusa and a tamale. Whatever the type, the tamales are always ready to eat, their steaming husks always waiting for your devouring abilities. This means you pay and you get food in the same minute. A few minutes later, usually just as I finish the tamale, a bad ass pupusa comes out of the kitchen with a little cabbage and a single serving of respectable salsa on the side. It shuts me up for a while, and that's saying something.

It's a salt and fat fest, but that's what you're here for. Also, the price of my standard meal with a Jarritos is less than the cost of a burrito in most places making it a pretty rare deal.

If you can get in before it closes shop (very similar to La Palma), get your grub on. You'll be glad you did.
author: Sean K.

description: Hands down best tamales EVER.  They grind their own corn for homemade, delicious masa. Ahhh so good!  Also very impressed with their beef taco. Chips were a tiny bit over done for my taste but the salsa was excellent!  Incredibly delicious food, tiny hole in the wall spot, very cheap. What a find!
author: Kate G.

description:
This place has the best pollo asado burrito I've ever had. I typically go for carne asada but their super chicken burritos are out of this world:
- perfectly grilled chunks of saucy chicken every time
- avocado chunks
- the rice and bean ratio is just right. Not too much or little
- same with cheese and sour cream

The only petty gripes I have are
- it typically takes about 20min to get my order
- I dont live inside their kitchen.
author: Patrick C.

description: Good quality Mexican food with a traditional feel.  The staff is friendly and accommodating to me even as I ask a lot if questions about items that I can't pronounce.  Food also comes out fast. Seating and tables are bare bones.
author: Andy C.

description:
FOOD: Epic nachos. So tasty. Large chunks of meat, a sliced up half-avocado. The cheese is real and the portion size is huge for the price. Have also had the Milanese Chicken which was interesting. The menu is a little small, but everything I have tried on it is absolutely delicious. They have some soups which look very good but I haven't yet tried them.
SERVICE: Very friendly and accommodating staff. English is limited. Closes at 7:30 pm.
AMBIANCE: Looks like a family run place. Clean and also a little cramped.
author: Evan K.

description:
La Espiga de Oro is one of those super low key neighborhood haunts that look kinda iffy from the outside but serves incredibly good home cooked gourmet food on the inside. From the first moment those chicharones/chicharon (fried crispy pork belly) touch your lips, you'll soon forget that you're sitting in a generally yellow and brown store whose original colors you cannot decipher. We ordered chicharones salad, carne asada tacos, and the champurado (chocolate rice porridge with cinnamon). All were excellent! The champurado was a bit too cinnamony and mushy for me but it was ok for my friend. This place is a definite  must-try if you're craving well cooked crispy pork belly!!!

Staff speaks mostly in Spanish with limited English and the menu is almost entirely in Spanish, so be sure to know what you want before getting in line.
author: C D.

description:
This place has some really great food, and super friendly staff. 

I have been a few times for pupusas, they're delicious. I have tried their pupusas, their tamales, and their burritos. I would definitely recommend their pupusas: if you eat pork, get one with pork, if not, get one without (all of them are delicious).

For lunch 3 of us shared:

QUESO PUPUSA: served with salsa and pickled cabbage YUMMY.
QUESO Y FRIJOLES PUPUSA: served with salsa and pickled cabbage YUMMY.
SUPER CARNE ASADA BURRITO: Very good burrito (make sure you get super'd)
CHIPS Y SALSA: You know... it's the measure of a place... and their chips and salsa are both AWESOME.

Another tip: you can buy chips, salsa, and tortillas (all house-made) here.

Looking forward to trying their champurrado, and their tacos!!!
author: Lani N.

description:
Worst Burrito I've had in San Francisco. 

You know, it isn't hard to find a good taqueria in the Mission. So I've taken to branching out and trying every one if them I can find. Encouraged by the four stars here on Yelp, I gave Espigo a go. 

Yuck. 

The first bad sign was when I opened the salsa that came with the chips. It clearly came from a jar -- it had that viscous liquidity that jar salsas have. 

Then, biting into the burrito, I discovered a similar but different salsa inside it. I guess I just want FRESH salsa, not some preservative-laden bile. Perhaps this nearly congealed state of salsa is some regionalism gone wrong, but authentic or no, it just wasn't good. This salsa was the opposite of dressing up a pig. Dressing down the girl next door?
author: Brent D.

description:
screw farolito or taqueria this place is the shit!

tastyyy tasty chicken burrito and solid salsa - just wish I loved closer!

*drools*
author: Carly M.

description: Simple, fresh, tasty. Homemade chips and tortillas. Fresh avocado on both of our dishes was a nice touch (Milanesa de res o pollo and vegetarian nachos). No salsa bar but their hot red salsa was good and plentiful. I'll be back.
author: Victoria K.

description: Cashier was super friendly and patient (she described all of the soups). The chicken soup and beef soup were amazing....fresh and didn't taste greasy! They added a half ear of corn, tortillas, and a small side order of rice. The food the other patrons were eating looked really tasty.
author: Johan S.

description:
This restaurant is a small eatery on 24th street in the Mission.  It's surrounded by a lot of other mexican restaurants similar to it so there are a lot of other options just on the same block.  To me, it did not do anything to stand out from the others and was rather mediocre.  They're most known for their "pupusas" which are fried bread stuffed with various meats.  I came here and ordered a carne asada super burrito.  The food was extremely oily and was bland in taste.  Moreover, it took over an 30 minutes for us to get our food.  It was made fresh, but it seemed a little excessive for our line.

If you need a place to eat, this is OK but there's better options in the mission for similar prices.
author: Robert T.

description:
The Yelp reviews were good, so even though it looked a little iffy, I figured I could trust it.  BAD IDEA!.  Four hours after eating my stomach felt awful, and I ended up being sick the rest of the night.  I found out the next day that my friend who also ate the food there also got sick.  And its pretty obvious why...

When I walked back to the bathroom I noticed large bins of raw chicken just sitting out, scattered around the back next to the mops and other supplies, along with a bunch of other food just sitting open, unrefrigerated and uncovered.  Everything was dirty and a mess with flies all over the food.  The guy making the food was moving around dirty equipment and then preparing the food with his bare hands.  It worried me a bit, but I have a strong stomach and was really hungry and I figured if the food was hot it would kill the bacteria and fly larva.  Nope, got sick anyway.

I checked their San Francisco health inspection scores... sure enough... improper food storage, vermin infestation, dirty utensils, unclean hands and not using gloves.  The same thing has been going on there for years.  They still haven't learned and probably never will.  

AVOID!
author: Jason O.

description:
La Espiga De Oro's hood has la cocina, la victoria bakery, and tortas los picudos so their food must be good to be still hanging around. 

menu: pupusas, tortas, burritos, tamales, etc. 

Sampling:
-burrito (6) carna asada, very large burrito, enough for  2 meals for most people but not me ...nice spicy salsa, grilled beef, grilled flour tortilla, choice of black or pinto beans, and rice. pretty near excellence!
-chicken tamales (1.85), (10 choices available)
very tender corn masa, tender breast meat within, nice hint of spiciness.
probably the best tamale  i've eaten. they're won some awards around town also.
-fried tortilla chips and salsa, chips tasted pretty fresh. homemade?
-jalepenas and sour carrots gratis also.

frijoles refritos:
-numero uno.
-free parking on side streets.
author: Victor G.

description: Amazing lupus as and the best service in the world!   We came with our 1 and 5 year old and they took care of us the minute we walked in.   You can not go  wrong here.  The caldos are amazing too.
author: JP M.

description: The most supercilious grub in the Mission. Their carne asada is marinated to perfection and cooked to order and no microwaves here making the nachos a wet (and cheesey) dream of flavors galore.
author: Kristofer B.

description: This is my go-to place for burritos in the Mission. The food is delicious, the staff is friendly and the prices are more than reasonable. My ONLY complaint is that this is not exactly "fast-food" - they make it from scratch which means you might have to wait a bit before the food is ready. If you know what you want, I'd recommend calling in advance with your order. Anyway, I definitely recommend it.
author: Mikhail S.

description: Real good. Even the veggie burrito is so amazing. Like a spicy orange sauce in it and avocado too. The pork pupusa was the best, definitely order that. The tamale was good too. But the burrito and pupusa were really memorable
author: Rose H.

description: This is seriously the best and most authentic central american restaurant in the mission. It's sort of cheap too, so you can try a bunch of things and not go broke. I highly recommend the pupusas, tamales and atole. Great people there too, will make you feel like you've traveled there:)
author: Esther F.

description:
If I were more of a hipster, I wouldn't be writing this review. I'd like this place to stay a secret, MY secret, inconspicuously sandwiched in between the yelp behemoths of El Farolito and La Palma. But I'm not. Ladies and gentlemen, this place is the real deal.

Everything I've ever gotten from here has been excellent. They have an extensive selection of tamales in various styles. Though all are good, I particularly recommend the sweet ones for something unusual that you can't find at the myriad other taquerias on 24th. Their chicharrones are the best I've ever had, they're one of the few places that serve pozole on the daily, and their standard carne asada burrito is magnificent. 

Throwing a  taco dinner party? Need to impress a would be Abuelita? They also make cheap homemade tortillas to order by the dozen. They're just as good as La Palma's and sooo beat the storebought variety. They continue to make and sell them into the late afternoon, so they're still warm and fresh by dinnertime.

God I love this place.
author: Kyle M.

description:
For those whom claim (either through sheer malice or lack of education) that El Farolito is the platonic ideal of a Carne Asada burrito, allow yourself to tarry a mere 1,000 yards east on 24th Street, to the sun drenched hinterlands near Potrero Hill, where you will find the unassuming awning of La Espiga De Oro ready to shade you from the hype shined upon other burrito-making luminaries hawking their gastronomic wares on Slab Row. 

The magic begins the moment you open the warm foil which encases a perfectly grilled-to-flaky tortilla, lovingly handmade in the back of the shop every morning. Bite into the burrito and you'll find howling spice, perfectly melted cheese, an ingredient mix which leaves no element overemphasized, extraordinary distribution of rice and beans, liberally applied avocado and some totally rad Carne Asada. A pause is in order to discuss this Carne, made from top sirloin, and grilled to smokey perfection, its saucy magic infusing every bite of the behemoth urban-food log which it resides within. As for the size of the burritos produced here, Brobdingnagian is probably the best (and most-polysyllabic) descriptor. To say that La Espiga makes the best Asada burrito in the Mission District is not hyperbole.

In non-burrito related business, the tamales are outstanding (go for the Guatamalen!) as are the pupusas (especially with Chicharrones...be still my heart!). Chips are freshly made (you can see them frying in back) and the salsa appropriately scorching. Service is extraordinarily friendly, and they'll go out of their way to remember a repeat customer. Expect to hear no English spoken after you place your order, Banda music blaring, and for the yellow walls to leave vivid afterimages playing upon your eyelids when you lean back and close your eyes in burrito-eating bliss.

Eat your heart out Farolito, La Espiga De Oro has won me over!

Extras:

This was the site of the last rated burrito on the dearly-departed bastion of super-burrito rating: Burritoeater.com.

Accessible by 48-Quintara/24th Street, 33-Stanyan, and all Mission corridor bus lines (including BART).
author: Casey U.

description:
Great service with a smile, good prices. I only ate here once and I only had a carne asada burrito so I can't speak about all their dishes but be warned that the grease can be overwhelming. 
If you have outrageous metabolism and a high tolerance for oily foods, you would've loved my burrito. It was very tasty but I had to leave it only half eaten. I'm sure digesting this half burrito will take me a good day and a half.
author: Marlin L.

description:
You can't ever go wrong with their pupusas!

Clean location fast service and the price is totally right!
author: Conchita B.

description:
Dropped by early this morning to buy tamales for breakfast.  Couldn't resist buying some tortilla chips, too.
Such a great inexpensive place for genuine Mexican food!
author: Philip C.

description:
My mouth has been lucky enough to devour the best pupusas I've ever had. 

This place may not look like much from the outside, but La Espiga De Oro is seriously the crème de la crème of PUPUSAS (at least in the Mission and possibly the whole Bay Area) . I ordered the revueltas papusas and holy crap I practically came on myself. The masa had a slight crisp to it (which I LOVE when I eat pupusas) and the whole thing was cheesy and meaty and just a whole lot of goodness!!! These bad boys were also quite big - one already got me pretty full! 

And their chicharones...I normally hate eating anything extremely fatty, but my goodness those things were irresistible. Definitely very hard, very crunchy, and very good. 

This place takes their time to make fresh, quality meals. I haven't had anything else, but I'm sure they're just as good. BUT MY GOD GET THE PUPUSAS!!!!
author: Tee C.

description:
What a hidden gem. I randomly came here during my lunch hour and saw Chicharrón in the window. Low and Behold...heaven in a plastic baggy. Yes, they should definitely have this sold on street corners world wide. 

Do yourself a favor, roll here and get a carnitas burrito with chicharron, OR their tacos. LEGIT. I wish there was options for toppings like Pico de gallo, but I'm grateful for spots like these. At Home, you can even save the chicharrons for later, reheat them at 350 degrees for 10 minutes, crispy goodness. Then get your siracha sauce and squeeze some lemon juice in it for a good dipping sauce.
author: Brian C.

description: Love this place. Delicious chicken mole, homemade tortillas and Guatemalan tamales.  My only complaint is that they have pepian on the menu, but it's never available.
author: beverly l.

description:
This place is great.  I might up the stars after another visit, hard to say after just a few selections.

I had a tamale.  Rockin'.  The maize flavor came through beautifully.  I had a very simple one without meat, just beans, cheese and jalapeno.  I could eat these every day.

Had a carnitas taco on the house tortillas.  You have to ask if you want the house tortillas for your taco, she said it cost more, but it's so inexpensive here that it's hard to see how it matters.  It was excellent.  The carnitas were less crispy than some places, but full of flavor.

I asked about the chicharron that everyone talks about.  The woman in the window gave me one to try.  It was totally unique and very tasty.  I will have to try the chicharron burrito, but I doubt I can eat a whole one.  Maybe Baby Spike can share a small piece of his when we go together.

The service was great.  Sure, it's not much to look at when you're in there, a few tables and a counter.  It felt like Mexico to me, the same kind of opening to the street and weird setup inside, so it was comfortable.  

Some people were eating a soup that looked great, have to try that.  I think I will keep going until I have tried everything on the menu.  I also bought some of their house-made tortillas, the thick kind made with corn.  Made chorizo tacos (found some great chorizo on Mission Street) for dinner and they were terrific.
author: Spike S.

description: Really yummy. Under the radar. Locals go here. All is made slowly and to order. Amazing tamale selection, including dessert tamales. WOW!
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is the best Mexican and Guatemalan food establishment in the Mission, hands down. I have visited many of the other restaurants various times (La Palma, El Farolito, Doña Tere's, La Taqueria, El Metate, Papalote, etc) and La Espiga wins on all counts -- quality of food, customer service,  price -- except for the lack of a salsa bar and the weird hours they keep. The women that work at this restaurant run a tight ship!! Being a fluent Spanish speaker does help in placing an order -- much of the clientele and virtually all of the staff are Mission locals, although these Yelp reviews have spurred more visitors from other neighborhoods and cities. 

Here are the things that I have enjoyed at La Espiga:
-Super Carne Asada Burrito: The meat is AMAZING. Perfectly cooked, never gristly or tough, has just a touch of browned crispy bit on the outside of each piece, and always is a generous helping. There is a sizable amount of cold crema and fresh avocado wrapped into the crispy-yet-chewy tortilla. They also know how to wrap the burrito so that the fillings are well-distributed so that every bite is perfect. It's best to stick to carne asada rather than any other filling (I've had the veggie and the carnitas ones, respectively, and they are not as great). 

-Super Carne Asada / Carnitas Tacos: The meat is always perfectly cooked. Do yourself a favor and ask for a "tortilla a mano" (handmade tortilla) instead of a "regular" tortilla -- it's slightly thicker/puffier, always piping hot, and part of the reason that these tacos are the best I've had in the Mission. These tacos also come with pickled vegetables on top, which are a fabulous and unique addition to add some vinegar-y goodness to all the dairy and meat goin' on.

-Atol de Nuez (a cornstarch drink made with walnuts): If you want a soothing, filling warm drink on a foggy SF morning (the place opens at 6am...), opt for this. 

- Pupusas de Frijol con Queso / Revueltas: Best pupusas in the Mission, as well. The repollo (marinated cabbage slaw that comes with an order) is to die for -- I always slather it over the top of the pupusa. and the salsas that La Espiga has are always fresh and with the right amount of spice. 

-Flautas: This is probably the only item I've had from La Espiga that was less than stellar. The flautas are just average flautas. 

-Tamales de Pollo: Dynamite. Generous portion of chicken, the masa is always moist, and the tamales are a pretty good bargain.

-Tortilla chips: Just to explain how good these are, it suffices to say that other restaurants in the neighborhood go to La Espiga to purchase chips to serve to their customers. 

-Frijoles/Arroz: Very dependable when ordering a platillo (entree-sized plate that normally has sides).

This place is amazing.
author: Ariel W.

description: By far the best damn burrito I've had the pleasure to put in my mouth. Super authentic, the cheese is perfectly melted, carne asada marinated to perfection, their homemade chips and salsa are killer. A simple and delicious pleasure. In an ocean of taquerias out here, I come out of my way and pass about a dozen just to eat here.
author: Cat O.

description:
I ordered a super chicken burrito, the chicken was way too salty, not as big as you would think it would be, not enough cheese and no sour cream. The salsa looked like it was just tomato paste, but the chips were good.

Won't be going back.
author: Rose H.

description: Insanely great carne asada burrito. I got the super option (for sour cream and chunks of avocado). High quality steak, flaky tortilla, and quality ingredients. Carnitas taco was great, too.
author: John J.

description: We saw this place through a Zagat review and decided to make the trek over from the East Bay.  Pupusas were good, tomales OK.  Otherwise, the dining experience was less than enjoyable with an overflowing trash can near our table, and the whole place was FILTHY.  Its a wonder the health department hasn't shut them down.
author: David S.

description: best. papusas. ever. i've only ever come here for the papusas , but if they are any indication of how yummy the other items on the menu are , i'll have to come back for those too ! frijol and queso (bean and cheese) papusa was their favorite, and ours too !
author: Nancee C.

description:
La Espiga De Oro (Golden Ear of Corn) is truly a neighborhood gem and dangerously close to my house. There are a few key points of interest at L.E.d.O. 

One cannot and should not leave without ordering a Guatemalan tamale. This is no mortal tamale. Instead, you get a rather hefty sized packet of the silkiest masa you have ever encountered enclosing an entire braised chicken drumstick, all wrapped up in a banana leaf. The masa is amazing, so creamy and savory; these are addictive.

One also cannot and should not leave without purchasing a bag of chicharrones by the lb. The owner explained to me that they don't just fry pork skin, they use actual long, thick strips of meaty pork belly for their chicharrones. Although they are amazing chopped up and put into burritos and tacos, I like to serve pieces of them for an indulgent pre-dinner bite. 

The owner also explained that not only does L.E.d.O. make their own masa and tortillas, but they also grind the corn to make their own flour. The tortillas are good, but my favorite are the bags of house-made tortilla chips, so good! These are not thin and wispy chips, they are rather substantial and will stand up to all salsas and dips. 

The pupusas are freshly made and also quite good. 

Other than a few small tables and a few counter seats, there's not a lot in the way of ambiance or seating.
author: Candice L.

description:
La Espiga De Oro, I hate to say this, but I think I am falling in love with you. I hope this does not change what we had before, but still, I hope our relationship can grow into something more. You know how I used to just like to casually stop by when I was hung over and pick up a few chicharrones to change my outlook on an otherwise miserable day. I could see that you had so much more to offer, but all I could think was "DAMN, your chicharrones are the shit!" 

But today, I was looking for something more than delicious, juicy deep-fried pork belly. I was really fucking hungry after coming back from the produce store, and then I knew: it was time to take this casual fling to the next level. Your pupusa was calling my name, and I needed to dive in and take a taste. Yes, combination, YES, I want to take all you have to offer in a homemade pocket of masa goodness into my mouth. I decided to be classy and wait till I got you home to take my first taste, though.

It was worth every second of the wait, baby. Your pupusa was cooked perfectly, just gooey enough, but not too dry and corny. Filled with just enough cheese, crispy pork, and refried beans to make a man really happy. And now, I want more. I may just leave El Farolito to get a piece of your burrito, and I have a real need to taste that taco meat. Is it as juicy as I think it will be? I hope so.

I don't even care that your English ain't so great baby, we hardly need words with all you are putting into my mouth. Yea, your salsa ain't really up to par, but I can make my own. You get 5 stars in my book, all the way. Please don't let me down. But even if you do, I'll still come back for the chicharrones.
author: Owen R.

description: Pupusas are to die for!! $3 for golden crisp outside, soft rich heavenly bean and cheese inside served with yummy salsa and pickled veggies. Randomly walked in and got lucky :)
author: Nina N.

description:
4.5 stars
Where have you been all of my life? Man - this joint rocked! Had a tamale and veggie taco. Both were just -- wow! Tamale was ultra-fresh - - good masa/cheese/jalapeno ratio. The veggie taco was different - rice/beans/cabbage/fresh jalapeno/secret sauce/avocado -- tasty - filling. Got a few house-made tortillas to go that were perfect the next day crisped on the stove-top w/ butter. The staff are so sweet, attentive, and accommodating. Place could use a little more love in terms of keeping clean after patrons eat but it wasn't sketchy. Will be back soon to try breakfast items!
author: Carson R.

description: Hole in the wall. Tasty, fresh, authentic food. Crunchy chicharon dishes. 'Nuff said.
author: Mike M.

description:
I finally had my first burrito de pollo asado and I've got to say it rivals the best I've tasted in the Mission.

As I sit here I'm glancing at the heel of the burrito, trying to muster the wherewithall to finish this delicious log. I just can't seem to take another bite yet.  It's still standing upright here on my desk (proudly, with that gaping grin burrito's have) daring me to hit it.  Dammit I will finish you Espiga burrito 'cause by gods I aint disposing of it anywhere but in mah belly!

Why so good?  Lemme start by saying I was pleasantly surprised by a particular ingredient largely under appreciated by burrito aficionados -  the flour tortilla.  None of that "manky" wet dishtowel taste.  Not the near-flavorless chewy blanket we're all accustomed to.  It's delicious, fresh-tasting, grilled until it's flaky just-so and worth every one of the hundreds of calories required to wrap and contain the innards of a super burrito.  

Inside the log, tasty bits of chicken simmered in a sublime tangy salsa roja dances with the taste buds and piquant chili warms the throat.  This lame purple prose of mine is making me want to bite it again despite the gurgling warnings of my gut.  Onion, cilantro, tomato, cheese, earthy pinto beans green chili - it's all in there in almost ideal proportions.  It's dripping a little on account of that simmered chicken however I did not mind licking my hand clean.  

I might lick your hand clean too if you tell me where it's been before it gripped an Espiga-rrito!  No, not really.

Anyway, until today I went to The Golden Ear for it's tamales and pupusas  - which are both excellent.  Their masa rocks.  Their curtido is delicious.  They don't make your pupusa until you order it so give em a few tics and you'll be rewarded with a toasty, melty treat (yes... even those bits of crunchy cheese that burst from the pupusa :) ).  The tamales?  All in the masa.  Not chewy overkill, light and full of corn flavor. 

Mkay I think I've worked off a portion of the burrito typing this novelette so Imma bite it again and see how it tastes cold.  Yep.  Still better cold than most others are hot.  Somehow I've got to find the room to eat the heel of this amazing tortilla.. I just can't let this thing beat me!  Ugh, Imma pay dearly for this over indulgence later tonight.  You'll find me on my couch, making walrus noises, tossing invisible sand upon my distended belly.  
Is it bad that I don't care?
author: Ben S.

description: Cook the tortilla on the pan until there are brown flakes all over, giving it a crisp texture while still being soft enough to sink your teeth into. Deep fry the salty little bits of chicharrón like it is chicken so it's crunchy as fuck. Stuff up the insides of the tortillas with a thick layer of something resembling cheese and sour cream. Mix small sticky rice with some salsa. Stuff in in the salty chicharron along with the rice, the salsa, a teeny bit of soft beans and now, marvel at one of the finest burritos to ever exist. Serve it up with a kind smile and a warm heart.
author: Abi R.

description: Unique and delicious. I ordered pupusa of chicharon con queso, burrito of carne Asada, Huarache Tamal and flautas. The flavors were sensational.
author: Jorge Z.

description:
Can't even describe how good the chicharrones are.
So meaty, crunchy, salty good...
Need to try something on the menu asap.

One note: there was this chicharrones trend a while ago, and everyone buying skin cracklings and raving about a specific producer. Sorry guys, you are all wrong, and this is how SF can be superficial sometimes, almost entitled to be trendy without a reason. 
Good lord, try one of these chicharrones and you won't go elsewhere for your porcine cravings.
author: Dario B.

description: go up to the hot food window and pick up some tamales, burritos, chicharon (like a giant unsliced piece of deep friend bacon).  Don't worry, they speak english.   I like to eat food here, take my bacon to humphrey slocumbe and dip it in my ice cream.   mmmm.  I'm real mexican and this is legit.  Gotta stop 1- here (food) , 2- humphry slocombe (ice cream), 3- philz (coffee), 4- dynamo donuts (reads and dessert) for my food tour of the mission.
author: rosalinda f.

description: I cannot speak any higher about the carnitas burrito. This is is the one you tell your kids about.
author: AJ G.

description:
I just realized I haven't reviewed this place yet! Geez... 

Well, let's start by noting that they have some of the best pupusas that the mission has to offer. Not too many choices for filling (cheese, beans or chorizzo), but we're talking quality here. I haven't explored that much else on their menu, but I had a few bites of burrito and the tortilla was extremely delish (does anyone know if they're home made?). 

To top it off they have some if the friendliest staff. Judging by the clientele and the fact that I did my order in spanish, they seem to cater less to the Humphry Slocomb hipster and more to the "real" latino/a. Still, my two fixie-riding friends who came with me felt pertty welcome. 

Come here if you want legit pupusas for a reasonable price and are tired of the Valencia yuppiness.
author: Elena C.

description:
I haven't gone to all the Mission hot spots for Mexican, but this is hands down the best burrito in town.

The Carne Asada Burrito was unreal, the juicy flavors were just amazing.

5 stars across the board!
author: Jordan G.

description: Simply the best carnitas and chicharones in San Francisco.  Excelent pupusas as well.  Not much on atmosphere, but definitely worth a visit!
author: Paul S.

description:
La Espiga De Oro is an interesting place, seems to be new as only has less that 50 reviews. The interior appeared to be like half taqueria and half grocery store. I read others reviews that this place has "the best burrito." I had the carne asada regular burrito and it was decent but not all that great. I told the woman taking the order to not include salsa or pico de gallo and sure enough it came with it, a little disappointed I forged on. The steak was cooked nice and was tasty, the beans and rice were standard and the tortilla had a little crunch. I fount the burrito to be a little greasy towards the last bights. Deffinitly not a great burrito from the mission.

On the other hand I had the chicharone con quesso papusa (pork and cheese.) They were great with fresh carnitas inside and perfect cheese to meat and massa ratio. Fair sized and fair priced, if I ever go back I will definitely order more papusas and probably would give their tamales a try as they seem to be the item most ordered. Takeout is common and recomended as their tables are small. Friendly customer service and we were given a few free 1/2 oz. samples of horchata like rice drinks.
author: Trev D.

description: Went back and had the tamales.  They weren't fresh or very tasty.  I'd still go there for a burritto but definitely wouldn't venture back to the tamales.
author: Ric S.

description:
Stopped here on a whim.  The tamales, sweet and savory ones, are plentiful and delicious.  I had the black bean, cheese, and jalapeno tamale and ordered a plain sweet corn one to temper the jalapeno heat between bites.  

My husband had the chile relleno pork entree with rice and beans.  He loved the meal and the terrific tortillas on the side.  Best I've ever tasted in the Mission.  

Some special things to note during our visit:

*The USA scored against Ghana to tie it 1-1.  

*The "Foodie Adventure" tour with Chris Milano stopped by and we learned about the quality of pork belly they use and the effort and ingredients to make the tamales. 

*The nice woman taking our order informed us after we mentioned it was our first time her that "they had been waiting for us".  

Now I know the last one sounds cliche but this place feels authentic.  Good fresh ingredients in a friendly and unpretentious atmosphere.  Who doesn't want that?
author: Colleen C.

description:
Taste: so good I still have to give 3 stars after the 10 I'm taking away for the stomach flu the delicious regular pollo burrito gave me.

:/ I'd love to come back if I wasn't scared to now.
author: Miko B.

description: yum yum yum.  i.m a huge burrito fan and this place had super tasty chicken burrito, fresh fried chips, and great red salsa for ~$7
author: Greg T.

description:
Delicious.   All the right stuff in all the right places!

 I had been craving a burrito for a couple weeks and had sadly been unable to grab one...until today.  After  a trip to REI with the GF we took the short trip over to 24th and hit up a small, but highly recommended taqueria.  I got chicken super burrito, she got the carnitas.  
  Chicken was great, zero complaints.  Sour cream glued it all together, the whole pinto beans perfectly balanced with pico and toasty tasting chicken.  The burrito also held together until the end-not a drop spilled.  I was even indulging in the chips and salsa while eating said burrito.
  THe carnitas was a different story. Big perfectly placed chunks of carnitas were in each bite.  THey were slightly crunchy on the outside and o so tender on the inside.  Made with serious love.  Again, nothing overpowered the super carnitas burrito.  everything was balanced and it held together perfectly.  
  Next trip....the papusas and chicharrones!
author: Rob B.

description: I came here for the champurrado, having read the rave reviews on this very web site. I also ordered a couple of the sweet tamales (elote and pineapple). I'm sure their other food is delicious, but both the tamales and the champurrado were so sweet that I had to throw them out after a few tastes. (Disclaimer: I routinely halve the amount of sugar called for in most cake, cookie, and cupcake recipes.) I ended up making my own champurrado based on recipes from the internet, and I have to say it was way better--spicier, less sweet, and generally awesome. I should probably get a truck of my own or something.
author: Kristina B.

description: I live very close to this restaurant and frequent it often. As mentioned in previous reviews, their pupusas are definitely the item that sets them apart from the surrounding restaurants. Their tamales are fairly standard, with the vegetable one being my favorite as it is more unique and less bland. I feel they've increased their price over the last year, but still a good deal for the amount of food. One thing to note is they make their pupusas once ordered, so expect a decent wait when ordering them.
author: Erik V.

description:
i usually walk to this area to shop for produce at casa lucas. no matter how hard i try, i can't resist stopping in la espiga de oro to pick up some chicharrons. no, these are not the puffed up, styrofoam-y things you get at 7-11. these chicharron are bascially deep fried pork belly. yes, deep fried pork belly. they have a thin layer of fat sandwiched between some meat and crispy skin.
