true food porn. i take it home, put on some marvin gaye and then turn down the lights...
author: Rob D.

description: 3 stars cuz their tamales are DISGUSTING.  All masa and no filling, i asked the clerk if they had filling as this is the usual problem with street tamales, they lack filling and she said she didn't know. So I bought one and of course it was all dry, flaky masa with one small piece if chicken, their champurrado and warm drinks are always good though!
author: Eduardo M.

description:
what i ordered... super burrito w/ carnitas

hole in a wall place, you can eat in or take out or buy house made specialties such as tamales etc...

my burrito was ok, got good fillings but the carnitas though flavorful and plentiful was chewy and hard, because  it was made with a very lean part of pork. 

ambiance... so-so ( a bit unsanitary at the back side)
service... great ( the cashier who doubled as my server, warmly greeted me in and out of the place, and made sure i got everything i needed for my dish)
cost... $
author: Gors P.

description:
BEST sweet corn tamales ever! 
The cheese and jalapenos tamales, fabulous!
Actually... so are the chicken and the pork. I haven't tasted all they offer but I have tasted at least half of them. Not a bad tamale in the bunch!

Nice people, great prices! Plus the chicharrónes...amazing! There was nothing I didn't like!
author: Riann B.

description: jesus fucking christ this place is good - shits on el far with 1/15th the line. barely any gringos in there.
author: Phillip B.

description: The burritos at La Espiga De Oro are absolutely spectacular.  The tortillas are grilled, and the seasonings that they use just really kick it to another level.
author: Kenois M.

description: Best place for a cheese and jalapeno tamale. The vegetarian sort is hard to come by, but La Espiga De Oro does it right and it's cheap!
author: Valerie L.

description:
Stumbled upon this place as I was grazing the Mission District for a bite to eat.

$1.85 for an incredible Vegetarian Tamale? Hit me up!

I guiltily savored my tamale in the middle of the front bench seat of a truck. They were understandably jealous.

Solution? Go to La Espiga de Oro and get more tamales!
author: Rachel V.

description: La Espiga is a terrific place for breakfast in the Mission - open at 6 a.m.  Champurrado. Tamales. Huaraches.  All really yummy and freshly made.
author: Steve S.

description: I've tried almost everywhere in sf that sells chicharron. I've finally found a place that I'm satisfied with. Their chicharrons are always fresh ,crunchy and juicy, just DELICIOUS. the bf and I would travel across the city just to get some. (The reason why we gained 10lbs -_-)  .  The best chicharrons in the city!
author: Jewels Y.

description: Came by for some tamales: while the cheese one and the chicken one were nothing spectacular, the Guatemalan one was really good, save for my tongue being pricked by a tiny chicken bone shard...
author: Maximillian M.

description:
The tamales are excellent and cost about $2/each. I think they're the best tamales I've had in San Francisco. 

Very friendly service.

I also had a breakfast burrito, but it was super salty. But the tamales made up for it.
author: D L.

description: La Espiga stands out in general-- everything is fresh and flavorful and unique-- but their Guatemalan tamales (chicken or pork) and pupusas are AMAZING! They deserve their #1 rank on burritoeater.com. Amazing that so many people rave about mediocre taquerias and that so few have even tried Espiga.
author: Jeff S.

description: Update: I love this place so much, I even order huevos rancheros for dinner! hm! hm! yum! YUM!
author: Helen L.

description:
Wow! The food is quite good at this little 24th Street hole-in-the-wall. Although there is a lack of seating and getting food takes a bit of time from order to delivery, the quality is very good. How authentic can it be? It reminds me of being in Mexico, yet they also serve pupusas. 

Good place. Will go back again!
author: Martha G.

description: came back on sunday, 07/19 after the aids walk with my brother for a quick round of mexican style tamales. at 1.75, these warm tamales (pollo and puerco) were pretty solid. i still prefer the south american style ones wrapped in plantain leaves; however, these tamales have been the best mexican style ones that i've had in the city so far. even la palma's don't match up well. i'll have to compare their nacatamales and salvadoran style ones later. this place is still great for some cheap tamale action
author: Danny C.

description: Yep, this place rocks. Haven't been there enough to truly explore the menu, but the burritos are sooooo yummy and LARGE and the chips kind of make me want to take a bath in them. In a good way.
author: r l.

description: I had the best burrito I ever had in the Mission and perhaps in my life here at La Espiga.  I ordered the chicharron burrito since it was an uncommon menu item.  The lady at the counter let me taste their chicharron which included the crispy fried pork skin and fried pork attached to it.  This was hands down the best burrito I ever had (except maybe the CA sisig burrito from the Senor Sisig truck).  I've had a burrito from the Hapa SF food truck too where they include chicharron but they get soggy inside.  At La Espiga the chicharron is thick so however long it takes you to eat it, you will get a crunch in every bite.  Overall their burrito had amazing flavor. It's really hard to find parking nearby but it's worth driving around in circles to find a spot.
author: Kristy L.

description: Love the TAMALES!!! best ever- except once the rajas one wasn't cooked ..the masa was raw :-( but that hasn't stopped me from the regular pork tamales and the elote tamales ..they are soo good, and the champurrado is good too!Not many chairs though.. but still I take my tamales and eat as I walk
author: Jess S.

description:
As a Salvadorean, im disgusted that these pass for pupusas.

Save your time, and money and go to Balompie, that is unless you like Pupusas with more dough than anything else.
author: Arnold S.

description: After 3 years of intense research, I have concluded that La Espiga De Oro (The Golden Ear [of corn]) has the best pupusas (chicharrone in particular), champurrado, and nacatamales in the mission, and may just take the title fight in the mission tamale throwdown.  Baaad english (but extra sweet if you dust off your spanish, gringo) but nice folks.  Pupusas are generous and hand formed, and fried to a perfect crispy crust, Champurrado is thick with a warm and delicious spice, and nacatamales have a lovely chicken leg encased in a rich corn pudding with a spiced center and palm leaf wrapper.  Similar to the popular tamale salvadoreno, the nacatamale gives you delicious flavor and a silky texture without having to worry about an errant olive pit breaking your teeth.
author: Jamie B.

description: Wow wow wow. AMAZING tamales, pupusas, tortas...everything you could want from mission-style food. Really friendly staff and dirt cheap - maybe the best value for the money anywhere in the city to be honest. This place is a must-visit.
author: J L.

description: This is by far the best, made with love food. Their jalapeno and cheese tamales are fantastic and the champurrado is balanced, yet rich and flavorful. I suggest you also try their fried chicken tacos, so, so good!
author: Tapatia D.

description: I just tried their chicharrónes on a recommendation. They were great! I got two for $4.50 (though I probably only needed one). Great for eating on the go. I don't feel right giving it 5 stars without trying more of the menu.
author: Stuart T.

description: Authentic hole in the wall Mexican deli...they make great home style tamales....get them warm and many varieties....very cheap at $1 for one.
author: Jake S.
